title: Clive Palmer's QNI looked like trading while insolvent, says judge
text:
Mr Ward claimed the company was not insolvent so they were therefore not uncommercial transactions, as claimed by the general purpose liquidators who are still pursuing the Queensland billionaire over $100 million in debts over the $300 million QNI collapse.

Mr Ward told the court the company was solvent until it was placed into administration on January 18.

He defended the controversial security arrangement with Aurizon, which allowed a deferral of payments to the rail provider until January 18, saying it was all above board.

"This was a proper transaction made in good faith to deal with the problem with Aurizon," he said.

"This is a commercial response to a critical situation. The transaction was commercial."

General purpose liquidators made a number of claims against Mr Palmer in their closing submissions.

Justice Mullins warned she was "likely to take a red pen" to a number of claims against Mr Palmer which stepped outside the central focus of the case.

She also said Mr Palmer, who was not in court in Brisbane on Wednesday, would have to be given the opportunity to respond to the claims.

Advertisement

Mr Ward said a number of the claims against Mr Palmer were "gratuitous" and should be rejected.

He said the case against Mr Palmer and his companies had "changed dramatically" over the course of the trial, especially since the $100 million settlement with special purpose liquidators in August.

Under the terms of the settlement, the special purpose liquidators – who were seeking repayment of the $66 million in workers' entitlements which had been paid by the Commonwealth – claims of shadow directorship against Mr Palmer and trading while insolvent were withdrawn.

But general purpose liquidators have continued to make the claims against Mr Palmer.

Mr Palmer has claimed outside court that the only reason the general purpose liquidators were continuing the case was to ensure they got paid their multimillion-dollar fees.

Shane Doyle, QC, for the liquidators, said their expert witnesses showed Queensland Nickel was insolvent in October 2015, three months earlier than claimed by Mr Palmer's lawyers.

"It was foolhardy to say, on January 13, the company had the capacity to pay its debts," Mr Doyle said.

"If they say they had the money in the bank, why didn't they pay their debts? If QNI had the capacity to pay they would have."

Mr Doyle said Mr Palmer's expert witness Suellen McCallum had underestimated the precarious financial position of QNI.

The trial continues.
description: Clive Palmer's Queensland Nickel refinery has been accused of making questionable loans just days before it went into administration.
